page.title: 14E.Malling (Kent) for Fruit
page.content: Kent is the most important fruit - growing county in England. Fruit farmers, needing somewhere to turn to for help and advice, were responsible, with the help of Wye College, for setting up E.M.R.S (East Malling Research Station) on 23 acres of land at E.Malling in 1913. This location was chosen for several reasons. It is near the centre of the main fruit growing area of Britain. The deep, good loam soil is suitable for fruit growing - it holds water but drains well in wet weather. Initially the nearby railway was important, linking the Research Station, Wye and London. The useful work carried out in the early days attracted financial support from growers and the government. Nearby Bradbourne House with its 360 fertile acres was acquired in 1938.
